ram 0.0.0.9001
  • Reference
  • Articles
  • Changelog

Summary

ram is an R package and Shiny application for building and solving linear resource allocation models in agro-pastoral systems. Users can define resources (constraints), activities (technical coefficients and objectives), and solve the resulting linear program with sensitivity analysis on binding constraints. The package ships an interactive Shiny front-end with two modes: a solve mode for uploading/editing tables and running the model, and a builder mode that guides users to compose tables and hand them off directly to the solver. Both modes share validation, CSV/XLSX import/export, and results visualization, lowering the barrier for practitioners who are not fluent in mathematical programming.

Statement of need

Many agronomy and farm-planning teams need reproducible decision support for land, labor, and nutrient allocation, but available tooling often requires specialist coding knowledge or lacks guardrails for data quality. ram targets these users by combining a minimal R API with a structured Shiny UI, so domain experts can assemble models, check feasibility, and iterate without writing solver boilerplate. The package includes example scenarios (winter crops, mixed farms) and an optional builder-to-solver handoff that keeps column alignment intact. Validation ensures required columns, numeric types, and unique names, reducing common errors when sharing datasets across teams.

Software description

Implementation

ram is written in R [@R-base] and uses lpSolve [@lpSolve] for linear programs. The Shiny app is built with golem [@golem] and shiny [@shiny]; data tables use DT, and exports rely on openxlsx/utils. The builder → solver handoff uses JSON with base64 encoding to avoid URL parsing issues when opening the solver in a new tab. Validation helpers enforce schema and numeric checks for both uploads and inline edits.

Functionality

  • Solve mode: upload or edit resource/activity tables, set objective direction, run the solver, inspect optimal activities, plots, and sensitivity. Inline edits and uploads are validated before solving, and solver reports can be downloaded.
  • Builder mode: interactively add/remove resources and activities, with automatic column synchronization and CSV/XLSX export. A one-click “Open in Solver” button passes the current tables to solve mode.
  • Programmatic use: vignettes show how to define resources/activities, build a model, and perform scenario analysis directly in R, keeping scripted and interactive workflows aligned.

Quality control

Automated tests (testthat) cover validators and parser helpers. Example vignettes (winter crops with and without bounds, mixed farm) exercise the solver pipeline and plots. The Shiny app runs locally without external services; reviewers can install from GitHub, run testthat::test_local(), and launch ram::run_app(mode = "solve") or ram::run_app(mode = "builder") to reproduce the workflows.

Availability

  • Repository: https://github.com/PAS-AGRO-PAS/ram
  • Issue tracker: https://github.com/PAS-AGRO-PAS/ram/issues
  • License: MIT
  • Intended archive: Tag a release and archive on Zenodo/figshare to obtain a DOI for the accepted version.

Acknowledgements

This work was developed within the PAS-AGRO-PAS project. We thank collaborators and testers who exercised the builder and solver workflows and provided feedback on the validation and UI flows.
